summary.body: I've just been mulling over some of the figures in the estimates for BJH and here's a thing. Why is the estimated charge for electricity for the common parts and lifts nearly 75 per cent more for 2006-7 than for 2005-6? There's a figure of c.36,000 against c.21,000. What's the justification for a huge rise like that? Have residents in other blocks noticed a similar hike?
summary.subject: Service charge estimate for 2006-7

summary.body: Fellow residents, I'm intrigued to know how your electricity bills compare to mine - and what your advice is with regard to energy conservation and achieving good value on electricity bills I'm in a one bedroom flat, two residents. We have a fair amount of electrical items, though most are off throughout the day; we keep the water heater switched on 24/7. Lightbulbs are of the energy-saving variety. Our electricity bills came out at something like 220 for the quarter up to August and 260 for the quarter up to now. Averaging about 80 a month. We are doing the occasional meter reading in order to keep their estimates in check. Our electricity supplier is Good Energy - I do expect to pay a premium for renewable energy but have no idea how this compares to other Barbican residents. Any advice gladly accepted.
summary.subject: Your advice on electricity bills please

summary.body: Can anyone help me with this - i know this sounds really stupid and naieve, but i never really checked how much i pay on bills and stuff before, and then this morning just happened to open my electricity bill and actually looked at it - and it was 229 for a quater. I have no idea if this is expensive or not - it just struck me as quite a lot seeing that i don't have a TV or stereo, i don't cook and i'm only here part time. That seems a lot to me for essentially hot water and running a laptop a few hours a day. Am i wildely out and is this in fact reasonable? I'm with EDF, if that means anything to anyone.
summary.subject: ouch! electricity bill

summary.body: I've just had an electricity bill of 100. It's more than usual as they are usually 60 - 70. The strange thing is that I don't use any more hot water in winter than I do in summer (a bath and a sinkful of water per day) and washing machine on about twice per week. The only items I use more are lights but it seems a lot just for that. How do other peoples bills compare? Has anyone had a timer on their immersion heater which cuts bills significantly? Would be very grateful for any tips..
summary.subject: High Electricity Bill

summary.body: I've just received the letter notifying of the price increase from EDF.  I've been labouring under the impression that in the Barbican we are "tied" to EDF and it isnt possible to change suppliers.  Ideally i'd like to use a green supplier of electricity, and to be able to shop around for a better deal. Can anyone advise on this?  Thanks
summary.subject: EDF Energy

summary.body: We have just received from EDF Energy the annual review of our monthly direct debit payment. At the end of the year we owed 25 and it was proposed to increase our monthly direct debit by 8 - 96 in the year to come. After a lengthy freephone call, this was reduced after much haggling to an additional 5 a month - 60 a year. EDF have been overestimating our direct debits in this manner for some years and I once raised the matter with Ofgen. We now contemplate looking for another supplier and will be interested in others' experience of EDF and any other suppliers and any suggestions for an alternative supplier and problems in switching suppliers. Help!  PS. We wish the French SNCF had taken over running our railways rather than dabbling in electricity supply.
summary.subject: Electricity charges

summary.body: In the two years I have been here my monthly payment to EDF has risen from 25 to 40.  I just tried to use the Energy watch site to see if I can change my supplier.  BUT they all quote dual use e.g. gas and electricity and although they say they can save me 300 p.a. the unit charge is higher than EDF. Help has anyone changed, to whom and is it worthwhile?
summary.subject: Electricity charges

summary.body: I moved here six months ago and have had two very high electricity bills.  The original oven would appear to be the culprit.  Have those of you who have replaced the original oven noticed a significant reduction in their bills?
summary.subject: Original oven

summary.body: Hi - I've a strange question perhaps. I live in Ben Jonson and don't know where my electricity meter is. I've been getting estimated bills since I moved in and they seem high at 80 per month so I'd like to take an actual reading. Can anyone tell me where to find the little devil? Thanks
summary.subject: Electricity Meter reading

summary.body: Hello Has anyone switched from London Energy to another supplier? I've just been quoted 68 a year from Southern Electric, which is much lower than my current bill and sounds too good to be true. If you have any horror stories about them (or can allay my suspicions) I'd be grateful to hear from you. Thanks
summary.subject: electricity

summary.body: Hi there We have been living in a 1 bed (with study off lounge) apartment in speed house for 1 year and we were shocked to find monthly electricity bills are circa 30gbp. granted there are two people living in the apartment but we dont cook that often (ahem), dont shower that often (ahem!   ) so cant see where the electricity is being used. our hot water system is on a timer so is only on for 1-1.5hrs per day any help or personal experience would be greatly appreciated!
summary.subject: Extortionate Electricity Prices in the Barbican!!!

summary.body: Today may be an unlikely day to mention solar energy,BUT--does anyone know how much energy could be generated from solar panels or photo-voltaic cells on the available roof space of the Barbican complex. I would think there must be a hectare or so of roof--but I don't know. Has anyone ever investigated this?   Should they?  Would turbines be useful? How much could be saved if the complex was made more energy efficient? Does anyone care?  Should they?  I know that PV cells generate DC, as opposed to AC voltage, and that inverters need to used to convert to AC. there seems to be no objective info on this: it is a morass of propaganda, and difficult to form a conclusion.  Any website references? Or do you just Google "deluded enthusiasm"?
summary.subject: Solar panels
